      62             : 
      63             :   /**
      64             :    * The DOM Range spec requires that when a node is removed from its parent,
      65             :    * and the node's subtree contains the start or end point of a range, that
      66             :    * start or end point is moved up to where the node was removed from its
      67             :    * parent.
      68             :    * For some internal uses of Ranges it's useful to disable that behavior,
      69             :    * so that a range of children within a single parent is preserved even if
      70             :    * that parent is removed from the document tree.
      71             :    */
      72             :   void SetEnableGravitationOnElementRemoval(bool aEnable)

     299             :   /**
     300             :    * Scan this range for -moz-user-select:none nodes and split it up into
     301             :    * multiple ranges to exclude those nodes.  The resulting ranges are put
     302             :    * in aOutRanges.  If no -moz-user-select:none node is found in the range
     303             :    * then |this| is unmodified and is the only range in aOutRanges.
     304             :    * Otherwise, |this| will be modified so that it ends before the first
     305             :    * -moz-user-select:none node and additional ranges may also be created.
     306             :    * If all nodes in the range are -moz-user-select:none then aOutRanges
     307             :    * will be empty.
